nodes.name: Javascript Syntax
Is a set of rules for writing programs in Javascript.
Defines how Javascript programs are constructed.
Statements
Are individual instructions that Javascript can execute.
Usually end with a semicolon.
Declaration Statements
Are used to declare variables.
Can use "var", "let", or "const".
Var Declarations
Uses the "var" keyword.
Variables declared with "var" are function scoped.
Let Declarations
Uses the "let" keyword.
Variables declared with "let" are block scoped.
Const Declarations
Uses the "const" keyword.
Variables declared with "const" are block scoped and cannot be reassigned.
Expression Statements
Are used to manipulate variables and values.
Can include operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
Control Flow Statements
Are used to control the flow of execution.
Include "if", "else", "switch", "for", "while", and "do".
Function Declaration Statements
Are used to declare functions.
Include the function keyword, a unique function name, a list of parameters, and a statement block.
Return Statements
Are used to specify the value returned by a function.
Include the return keyword followed by the value to be returned.
Keywords
Are reserved words in Javascript.
Have special meaning and cannot be used as identifiers.
Control Flow Keywords
Are used to control the flow of execution.
Include "if", "else", "switch", "for", "while", and "do".
Declaration Keywords
Are used to declare variables.
Include "var", "let", and "const".
Function Keyword
Is used to declare a function.
Is followed by a unique function name, a list of parameters, and a statement block.
Return Keyword
Is used to specify the value returned by a function.
Is followed by the value to be returned.
Operators
Are used to perform operations on variables and values.
Include arithmetic, comparison, logical, assignment and bitwise operators.
Arithmetic Operators
Are used to perform mathematical operations.
Assignment Operators
Are used to assign values to variables.
Comments
Are used to add notes or descriptions within the code.
Are ignored by the Javascript interpreter.
Single Line Comments
Begin with "//".
Only apply to the line they are written on.
Multi Line Comments
Begin with "/*" and end with "*/".
Can span multiple lines.
Data Types
Are the types of values that can be manipulated in Javascript.
Include Number, String, Boolean, Null, Undefined, Object, and Symbol.
Primitive Data Types
Are the most basic data types in Javascript.
Include Number, String, Boolean, Null, Undefined, and Symbol.
Object Data Type
Is a complex data type that allows for the packaging of code and data together.
Can contain properties and methods.
Loops
Are used to execute a block of code a number of times.
Include "for", "while", and "do while" loops.
Functions
Are blocks of code designed to perform a particular task.
Are executed when they are invoked (called).
Function Declarations
Are used to declare a function.
Include the function keyword, a unique function name, a list of parameters, and a statement block.
Function Invocations
Are used to invoke (call) a function.
Include the function name followed by a list of arguments in parentheses.
Objects
Are complex data types that allow for the packaging of code and data together.
Can contain properties and methods.
Object Properties
Are variables that are used inside the object's methods.
Can be any of the three primitive data types, or any of the abstract data types, such as another object.
Object Methods
Are functions that let the object do something or let something be done to it.
Can be referenced by the "this" keyword.
Semicolons
Are used to separate statements.
Are optional in most cases, but best practice is to include them.
Strict Mode
Is a way to opt in to a restricted variant of JavaScript.
Eliminates some JavaScript silent errors by changing them to throw errors.
Can be switched on by adding "use strict"; at the beginning of a script or a function.
Sloppy Mode
Is the default mode of JavaScript before ECMAScript 5.
Allows certain actions that are disallowed in strict mode.
Can lead to unexpected results because of silent errors.
JavaScript Data Types
Exist in JavaScript to classify data for processing
Can be divided into primitive and complex types
Are used to specify the type of data that can be stored and manipulated within a program
Primitive Data Types
Basic data types provided by JavaScript
Include Boolean, Null, Undefined, Number, String, BigInt, and Symbol
Immutable, meaning their values cannot be changed
Represented directly at the lowest level of the language implementation
When assigning a primitive value to a variable or passing it as an argument to a function, its content is copied
Boolean
Represents two values: true or false
Used typically for storing yes/no values
Syntax: var x = true; or var x = false;
Null
Represents the intentional absence of any object value
It is one of JavaScript's primitive values
Syntax: var x = null;
Undefined
A variable that has not been assigned a value is of type undefined
A method or statement also returns undefined if the variable that is being evaluated does not have an assigned value
Syntax: var x;
Number
Used to represent numeric values
Can be created by literals or as a result of an expression
Syntax: var x = 123;
Integer Numbers
Represent whole numbers
Can be positive, negative, or zero
Syntax: var x = 123;
Floating Point Numbers
Represent numbers with decimal points
Syntax: var x = 123.45;
Number Literals
Represent numbers in various bases
Includes binary (base 2), octal (base 8), and decimal (base 10)
Syntax: var x = 0b11; (binary), var y = 0o10; (octal), var z = 35; (decimal)
String
Used to represent textual data
It is a set of 'elements' of 16-bit unsigned integer values
Syntax: var x = 'text';
Single Character String
Represents a single character
Syntax: var x = 'a';
Multi-character String
Represents a sequence of characters
Syntax: var x = 'Hello World';
BigInt
An integer with arbitrary precision
Can store large integers beyond the safe integer limit for Number
Syntax: var x = 123n;
Symbol
A unique and immutable primitive value
Often used as the key for an object property when the property is intended to be private for internal use within a class or object
Syntax: var x = Symbol('description');
Complex Data Types
Types that aggregate multiple values into a single entity
Include Object, Array, and Function
When assigning a complex value to a variable or passing it as an argument to a function, the reference is copied, not the content
Object
A non-primitive data type
Allows for the grouping of primitive and complex data types into a dynamic collection
Can contain properties and methods
Syntax: var x = {property1: 'value1', property2: 'value2'};
Object Properties
Represent values that are associated with an object
Syntax: var x = {property1: 'value1', property2: 'value2'};
Object Methods
Represent functions that are associated with an object
Syntax: var x = {property1: 'value1', property2: 'value2', method1: function() { // do something }};
Array
A special variable, which can hold more than one value at a time
Can hold numbers, strings, objects, other arrays, etc.
Syntax: var x = [value1, value2, value3];
Single Element Array
Represents an array with a single element
Syntax: var x = [value1];
Multi-element Array
Represents an array with multiple elements
Syntax: var x = [value1, value2, value3];
Function
A set of statements that performs a task or calculates a value
Can be defined using function keyword
Syntax: function name(parameters) {statements}
Function without parameters
Represents a function that does not take any arguments
Syntax: function name() {statements}
Function with parameters
Represents a function that takes one or more arguments
Syntax: function name(parameters) {statements}
Loops in JavaScript
Loops are a programming feature that allows a set of instructions to be executed repeatedly.
Loops in JavaScript include for, while, do...while, for...in, and for...of loops.
Each loop has a different syntax and use case.
Loops are used to reduce the number of lines in a program.
Loops continue to execute as long as a certain condition is met.
For Loops in JavaScript
A for loop repeats until a specified condition evaluates to false.
The syntax of a for loop includes initialization, condition, and iteration expression.
The initialization, condition, and iteration expression are separated by semicolons in a for loop.
The for loop is the most compact form of looping in JavaScript.
Initialization in For Loops
Initialization is the starting point of a for loop.
It is where we define and set up our loop variable.
The initialization statement is executed before the loop begins.
Condition in For Loops
The condition is evaluated before each loop iteration.
If the condition is true, the loop will start over again, if it is false, the loop will end.
The condition tests if a given condition is true or not.
Iteration Expression in For Loops
The iteration expression is invoked after each loop iteration.
It is typically used to update the loop counter.
The iteration statement can increase or decrease the counter.
Body of For Loops
The body of the for loop contains statements that are executed for each iteration.
The body of the for loop is enclosed in curly braces {}.
The body of the for loop can include multiple statements.
While Loops in JavaScript
A while loop repeats as long as a specified condition is true.
The syntax of a while loop includes a condition only.
The while loop executes a statement or code block repeatedly as long as an expression is true.
Once the expression becomes false, the while loop terminates.
Condition in While Loops
The condition in a while loop is evaluated before each loop iteration.
If the condition is true, the loop will start over again, if it is false, the loop will end.
The condition tests if a given condition is true or not.
Body of While Loops
The body of the while loop contains statements that are executed for each iteration.
The body of the while loop is enclosed in curly braces {}.
The body of the while loop can include multiple statements.
Do...While Loops in JavaScript
A do...while loop is similar to a while loop, except that it tests the condition at the end of the loop body.
This type of loop will execute the loop body once, before checking if the condition is true, then it will repeat the loop as long as the condition is true.
The do...while loop guarantees that the loop body is executed at least once.
Condition in Do...While Loops
The condition in a do...while loop is evaluated after each loop iteration.
If the condition is true, the loop will start over again, if it is false, the loop will end.
The condition tests if a given condition is true or not.
Body of Do...While Loops
The body of the do...while loop contains statements that are executed for each iteration.
The body of the do...while loop is enclosed in curly braces {}.
The body of the do...while loop can include multiple statements.
For...In Loops in JavaScript
A for...in loop is used to loop through an object's properties.
The syntax of a for...in loop includes a variable name and an object.
In each iteration, one property from the object is assigned to the variable name and this loop continues until all the properties of the object are exhausted.
Variable Name in For...In Loops
The variable name in a for...in loop is the variable to which each property from the object is assigned during each iteration.
The variable name is defined within the parentheses of the for...in loop.
Object in For...In Loops
The object in a for...in loop is the object whose properties are being looped through.
The object is defined within the parentheses of the for...in loop, after the variable name.
Body of For...In Loops
The body of the for...in loop contains statements that are executed for each iteration.
The body of the for...in loop is enclosed in curly braces {}.
The body of the for...in loop can include multiple statements.
For...Of Loops in JavaScript
A for...of loop iterates over any iterable – a data container that supports the iteration protocol.
Each iterated value is stored in a variable, as specified in the head of the for...of loop.
The syntax of a for...of loop includes an iteration variable and an iterable.
Iteration Variable in For...Of Loops
The iteration variable in a for...of loop is the variable to which each iterated value is assigned during each iteration.
The iteration variable is defined within the parentheses of the for...of loop.
Iterable in For...Of Loops
The iterable in a for...of loop is the data container that is being looped through.
The iterable is defined within the parentheses of the for...of loop, after the iteration variable.
Body of For...Of Loops
The body of the for...of loop contains statements that are executed for each iteration.
The body of the for...of loop is enclosed in curly braces {}.
The body of the for...of loop can include multiple statements.
Loop Control in JavaScript
Loop control statements change the execution from its normal sequence.
JavaScript supports two types of loop control statements: break and continue.
The break statement terminates the loop and transfers execution to the statement immediately following the loop.
The continue statement skips the rest of the loop and continues with the next iteration.
Break Statement in JavaScript
The break statement is used to exit a loop early, breaking out of the enclosing curly braces.
When a break statement is encountered, the program flow moves to the statement immediately following the loop.
The break statement can be used with any loop in JavaScript.
Continue Statement in JavaScript
The continue statement skips the rest of the loop and continues with the next iteration.
When a continue statement is encountered, the program flow moves to the loop check expression immediately and if the condition remains true, it starts the next iteration.
The continue statement can be used with any loop in JavaScript.
Labels in JavaScript
Labels are used in conjunction with break and continue to control the flow more precisely.
A label is simply an identifier followed by a colon (:) that is applied to a statement or a block of code.
Line breaks are not allowed between the ‘continue’ or ‘break’ statement and its label name. Also, there should not be any other statement in between a label name and associated loop.
